email_content:
Hi Mark,

Thank you for reaching out about student engagement in our classes. I appreciate the chance to compare notes and learn from each other.

Below are a few approaches that have been working well on my end lately:
• Begin with a thought-provoking question – opening each session with a brief prompt gets everyone thinking right away and frames the day’s discussion.
• Connect theory to lived experience – using recent news items or local case studies has sparked livelier exchanges and helped students see relevance beyond the classroom.
• Student-led segments – inviting small groups to facilitate part of the conversation or present a related example increases ownership and keeps the energy up.
• Quick pulse checks – a one-minute reflection poll or exit ticket at the end of class gives real-time insights into where students are engaged or confused.
• Break-out discussions – short, focused small-group work lets quieter students contribute before we reconvene as a class.

On the assessment side, I’ve been running a brief mid-term pulse survey to gauge engagement and adjust activities accordingly. If you’re interested, I’m happy to share the aggregated results once this semester’s survey closes.

I’d love to hear what you’ve found effective as well. Perhaps we could set up a short meeting or even co-host a teaching workshop for the department.

Let me know what you think, and thanks again for starting this conversation.

Best,
Jane
